Award.AwardTitle: Infrared Beacons in the Universe - J Band Spectroscopy of Red Supergiants and the Chemical Composition of Star Forming Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration: Determining the chemical composition of galaxies is crucial for understanding their formation and evolution. Standard techniques, utilizing emission line spectra of the diffuse interstellar gas (specifically HII regions), is plagued by large and poorly understood systematic uncertainties. This project will develop a new, and potentially transformative, approach based on near-infrared spectroscopy of individual red supergiant stars. The output of these stars peaks in the J-band, where the spectra are rich in atomic lines. New multi-object infrared spectrographs on 10-meter-class telescopes will be able to obtain sufficient resolution to derive accurate abundances to distances of 10 megaparsecs. The purpose of this project is to develop, validate and exploit this new technique, in several steps: (1) The technique will be tested in the Milky Way and the Magellanic Clouds, against complementary techniques using HII region and blue supergiant star spectra; (2) Local Group galaxies of extremely low metallicity (NGC 3109, WLM, IC 1613) and the spirals M31 and M33 will be studied and compared with results from blue supergiants; (3) the technique will be applied to spiral galaxies beyond the Local Group out to a few megaparsecs (NGC 300, NGC 2403, M81). Accurate abundances and abundance gradients will be obtained, allowing constraints on the evolutionary states and histories of star forming galaxies, as well as an assessment of the reliability of H II region techniques. The method will also be extended to super-star clusters, which contain many dozens of red supergiants dominating the J-band flux, and which may be useful as cosmological abundance indicators at even larger distances. Eventually, this technique may be best exploited by the next generation of large telescopes, achieving abundance measurements out to 100 megaparsecs, a substantial volume of the local universe. The project will support the work of one graduate student, who will participate in international collaborations. Results will be incorporated into education and public outreach activities conducted by the Principal Investigator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we have developed a completely new method to investigate the evolution of galaxies. We use very young and very massive stars, with masses 20 to 40 times heavier than the sun, in the late phases of their life as the tools of our method. When these stars age,  they expand and become very large with diameters as large as the solar system. At the same time these objects become much cooler than the sun and because of the lower temperature they shine in a red color. We call them red supergiants. Betelgeuze in Orion is an example for such a star.

Red supergiants are the brightest stars in the universe at infrared light. They are true beacons in the universe and can be detected in the images of galaxies at many million light years distance. Many times red supergiants are found in dense and compact star clusters of millions of stars, when these star clusters are older than eight million years. Then the clusters contain some hundred of red supergiants and the combined light of these produces a source of infrared light, which can be seen through a large telescope in a galaxies at hundreds of light years distance.

With modern spectrographs attached to the largest telescopes of the world such as the Keck Telescopes on Mauna Kea in Hawaii or the ESO VLT in Chile one can disentangle the infrared light of distant red supergiants into a spectrum, which shows spectral lines as fingerprints of the chemical elements. The strength of these spectral lines allows us to determine the chemical composition of the red supergiants.

For our project we first had to develop the theoretical tools to analyze the the infrared spectra of red supergiants to measure chemical composition. For this purpose we used a computer program which simulates the physical conditions in red supergiant atmospheres and calculates theoretical spectra. The calculations are complicated and technically chellenging but at the end the comparison of these calculated theoretical spectra with observations enables us to determine the chemical composition.

Of course, this very complex and complicated new analysis method needed to be tested. In a first step we analyzed red supergiant stars in our own galaxy, the Milky Way. We looked at objects in the solar neighborhood, where we know very well what chemical composition to expect. Only if our new method yields results in agreement with these expectations, can we be certain that ithe new approach is reliable. The first test gave very encouraging results. We were certain that we can determine the content of heavy elements in  a red supergiant stars with a precision of 20 percent. For the application to investigate the chemical composition of galaxies this an accuracy that is barely accomplished by other methods.

In an next step we tested the method with red supergiants in our neighbor galaxies, the Magellanic Clouds. The young massive stars in these galaxies have a chemical composition different from the sun. They are metal poor, which means they contain much less heavy elements than the sun. Our new method worked very well also for these metal poor objects confirming its precision over a wide range of chemical composition.

After these very encouraging results we applied the method to red supergiant stars in more distant galaxies, the Andromeda galaxy M31, the Sculptor galaxy NGC 300 and the giant spiral M83, in distances of 1 million, 6 million and 13 million light years, respectively. The results were impressive and we obtained very accurate chemical composition.

In a final step we studied red supergiants in the star clusters of the Antennae galaxies, a system of merging galaxies at 60 million light years distance. This was the first direct determination of stellar metallicities in these galaxies ever! Again, we obtained very convincing accurate results demonstrating the tremendous diagnostic power of our new method.

Our new method has an enromous potential of future applications. With the present day largest telescopes in the world we will be able to study the evolution of galaxies in a volume around our Milky Way with a radius of 100 million light years. I

With the giant telescopes of the next generation such as the Thirty Meter Telescope on Mauna Kea in Hawaii and the ESO Extremely Large Telescope in Chile our method will become truly important. These telescopes will use the new technology of adaptive optics which will be extermely helpful for our infrared spectroscopy of red supergiant stars. We will then be able to apply our method to red supergiants in stars clusters in galaxies of more than thousand light years distances. This will open an unprecedented volume of the universe for very detailed studies of the chemical evolution of galaxies.
